titleStmt.title: Stochastic Coding Detection Scheme in Cyber-Physical Systems against Replay Attack

affiliation.orgName: College of Information Science and Engineering
State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation of Process Industries
College of Information Science and Engineering
State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation of Process Industries

analytic.title: Stochastic Coding Detection Scheme in Cyber-Physical Systems against Replay Attack

biblStruct.note: Received date: 4 July 2018 Revised date: 16 November 2018 Accepted date: 31 December 2018 Preprint submitted to Information Sciences

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the security problems in cyber-physical systems (CPSs) against replay attack are considered. With replay attacks, attacker records and covers the transmitted data between the senders and receivers of the sensors. In order to achieve the detection objective for malicious replay attacks, the stochastic coding scheme is proposed to make the CPSs generate covariance differences between the normal and compromised data. Different from the existing results, this method detects the replay attack without sacrificing any system performances in normal systems. Based on the coding scheme, two types of detectors are further designed to detect the covariance changes in residual and output, respectively. Moreover, the output-based detector has more low-computing solution process than the residual-based one. Finally, a practical example is proposed to demonstrate the superiority of the stochastic coding scheme.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Highlights
div.p: • A stochastic coding scheme is proposed to generate covariance difference of the compromised data under replay attack. This scheme can remove the performance degradations in existing works.
• A residual-based detector is designed to detect the covariance changes caused by the coding scheme subject to the false alarm rate (FAR) and attack detection rate (ADR) limitations.
• Furthermore, a output-based detector is proposed instead of residual information. It can effectively reduce the design complexity of the residual-based detector.
• Different from traditional detector, the above residual-based and output-based detectors apply a novel form to remove the non-convex constrain conditions in design optimal problems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The emergence of cyber-physical systems is boosted by the rapid development of network communication technology. Such complex systems feature tight coordination between the information network and physical process. Many critical infrastructures are considered as CPSs, such as smart grid, transportation and medical monitoring. The complexity and openness have made CPSs vulnerable to malicious behavior in cyber fields, for instance, deliberately attack which sabotages facilities and inflicts economic damage. Thus, security is a significant focus for the deployment of CPSs and continue to attract many attentions in the view of control theory [5,9,19]. Recently, the researchers mainly focus on the stability and security of control systems equipped with networked communications [35,36,37], especially sensor networks [22,23]. To defense the malicious attack, the ability of detecting their invasion action becomes extremely important in the security challenges of CPSs [7,13,27,30].

The well-modeled attacks include denial-of-service attack (DOS), deception attack and replay attack. DOS attack hampers the transmission channels in the network layer, and some frameworks for modeling the attack actions are given in [8,16,34]. Considering finite attack times, an optimal DOS attack scheme against the remote estimator is provided to maximize the estimation error [33]. To stabilize the CPSs under DOS attack with constrained frequency and duration, a series of schemes based on ISS stable and Lyapunov theory is researched [14,20]. In [21], the secure consensus problems against DoS attacks in the multi-agent systems are researched, and the attacks occur in

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: the transmission channels of communication topology (the edges of the graph). Recently in [28], a detection and compensation mechanism is studied for a class of DoS attack, whose occurrence probability satisfies Bernoulli-distributed.

Deception attack refers to the behavior of modifying the transmitted information over the networks to influence data's integrity and availability and keep the intrusion stealth simultaneously [2,4]. In [18], the sensor and actuator attacks are both considered, and an adaptive secure control scheme against the attacks is designed with the known sign of the compromised sensor measurements. Furthermore, to improve the results in [18], a control scheme based on barrier Lyapunov function and Nussbaum function is studied [3]. In some results such as [10] and [32], the attacks or induced phenomena in CPSs are described as stochastic behaviors. A security control scheme is developed based on the input-to-state stability in probability(ISSiP) theory against a class of stochastic deception attacks, whose success probability obeys Bernoulli-distributed [10]. For multi-sensor fusion procedures, some different detection scenarios against deception attacks are investigated [17], where a novel type of detector is designed with both normal and compromised system information. In sensor networks, a novel filter structure is developed to achieve the distributed filtering with the credible measurements from each sensor itself and attacked measurements from its neighbors [11]. It is worthy to notice that the attacker may more or less acquire some information of system dynamics to implement an optimal DoS or deception attack [29].

Conversely, replay attack can destroy the CPSs even without any information of the external structure. For this reason, replay attack is the easiest attack to be implemented for malicious objectives. The attacker records and covers the transmitted data in network aspect such that it influences the close-loop features of CPSs and degrade the system performances. This attack form is frequently reported in industrial control systems. For example, Irans nuclear centrifuges accident is the most typical crisis caused by replay attack, which is achieved by Stuxnet. In this accident, centrifuges are forced to crazily rotate, but the anomalies are covered by replay attacks. Although this accident causes serious damage, it aroused people's attention to cyber security. Moreover, some accidents caused by replay attacks in water systems are reported in [1]. In fact, the detection of replay attack is difficult to deploy, but it is vitally important for system security. In [38], a recording-horizon control law is provided to deal with the replay attack over the communication network between controller and actuators. Under bandwidth constraints, a secure fusion estimation scheme is proposed for CPSs against replay attack [6]. An additional Gaussian signal is injected into the actuators to detect the replay attack when the system performances are sacrificed [26]. Based on this detection countermeasure, a stochastic game approach is developed to decrease the loss in control performance [24]. However, performance degradation implies life reduction of equipment or economic loss, and it is not accepted when systems run for years. Hence, a detection scheme without performance loss is urgently needed for the security problems in CPSs against replay attacks.

From the defender's standpoint, a detection method is developed against replay attacks on sensor measurements without performance degradation in normal systems. The detailed contributions are summarized as follows:

1) Firstly, a new stochastic coding scheme, which codes a Gaussian signal into the transmitted channels between the sensors and processors, is proposed to generate covariance difference of the compromised data. Then, the detection problem of replay attack can be transferred to find a test method for distinguishing the covariance changes in compromised systems.

2) In order to detect the covariance changes caused by the stochastic coding scheme, a residualbased detector is designed by the likelihood-ratio test subject to the given false alarm rate (FAR) and attack detection rate (ADR) limitations. Furthermore, since the output measurements are only influenced by the covariance changes in current time, we propose an output-based detector design method instead of using residual information. It is also effective to the systems without Kalman filters or state observers, and reduces the design complexity of the above-mentioned residual-based detector.

3) Different from the traditional χ 2 detector, the above residual-based and output-based detectors apply a novel form, which uses the compromised covariance information of the coding signal. With this method, the non-convex constraint in design optimization problems is removed.
4) For both residual-based and output-based detectors, the relationships between the covariance
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: of the coding signal, the threshold value of detector, the possibilities of false alarm and attack detection are established in the optimization problem. With the stochastic coding scheme and the novel detectors, the replay attacks are detected with the given FAR and ADR, and the performance degradation in [26] can be removed in the normal system. This paper is organized as follows: Section II presents the system models and some preliminaries about the replay attack. In Section III, the stochastic coding model is first introduced to elaborate the changes in compromised systems, and further residual-based and output-based detectors are designed based on the coding scheme, respectively. Finally, a practical example is given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the provided scheme.

div.head: Problem Formulation and Preliminaries
div.p: The CPS is modeled by the following discrete-time linear system:
div.formula: x k+1 = Ax k + Bu k + w k , y k = Cx k + v k ,(1)
div.p: where x k ∈ R n is the state vector, u k ∈ R nu is the control input and y k ∈ R m is the output vector of the sensor measurements. A, B and C are the known matrices with appropriate dimensions. (A, B) and (C, A) are assumed to be completely controllable and observable, respectively. w k and v k are the independent Gaussian random white noise, i.e.,
div.formula: w k ∼ N (0, Q), v k ∼ N (0, R). (A, √ Q) is assumed
div.p: to be controllable. The initial state x 0 is independent of w k and v k , and obeys x 0 ∼ N (x 0 , Σ).
In order to obtain the state estimations, the following Kalman filter is implemented by the principle of minimum mean square error.
div.formula: xk+1|k = Ax k + Bu k , P k+1|k = AP k A T + Q, L k = P k|k-1 C T (CP k|k-1 C T + R) -1 , xk = xk|k-1 + L k (y k -C xk|k-1 ), P k = P k|k-1 -L k CP k|k-1 .
div.p: According to the mentioned observability of (C, A), the time-varying Kalman gain L k , and error covariance P k and P k|k-1 will converge to a steady-state L, P and P , respectively. Then, the covariance P and P are obtained by the following equation:
div.formula: P = AP A T + Q -AP C T [CP C T + R] -1 CP A T , P = P -P C T [CP C T + R] -1 CP.(3)
div.p: The linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) controller is equipped to guarantee the stability of the system (1) and minimize the following index [26]:
div.formula: J = lim T →∞ min u0,••• ,uT 1 T E T -1 k=0 (x T k M x k + u T k N u k ) ,
div.p: where M and N are the positive semi-definite matrices. In the sequel, the control input is
div.formula: u k = -(B T U B + N ) -1 B T U Ax k K xk where U satisfies U = A T U A + M -A T U B(B T U B + N ) -1 B T U A.(4)
div.p: Assume that the attacker can record the data measured by the sensors and modify them at arbitrary times. When the sensor measurements are replaced by the past data, the compromised systems is modeled as follows: where y k is the past sensor output vector recorded by the attacker. It makes the estimations of the system states change, and indirectly influence the control performance. Notice that y k is generated by the past systems, whose initial value is equal to the real system, i.e., x 0 = x 0 and x 0|-1 = x0|-1 .
div.formula: x k+1 = Ax k + Bu k + w k , y k = Cx k + v k , xk+1|k = Ax k + Bu k , xk = xk|k-1 + L k (y k -C xk|k-1 ),(5)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The compromised systems architecture, attack processes and positions are shown in Fig. 1.
Assumption 1. The system parameters satisfy (A + BK)(I -LC) is stable.

Remark 1. When the replay attacks launch, the residual may converge or diverge. As it has been investigated in [26], if the system parameters satisfy (A + BK)(I -LC) is stable, the residual z k converges under replay attacks, otherwise, the residual diverges. In fact, when residual diverges, the evaluation value g k of detector is always larger than the threshold value after a certain time. As a result, the replay attack can be detected if residual diverges. However, when residual converges, the replay attacks are hard to be detected since the residual covariances in compromised and normal systems are same. Thus, we focus on dealing with this case. Here, the stochastic coding scheme will be designed to increase the residual covariance when replay attacks are launched.

Remark 2. When systems suffer from replay attack, the closed-loop control structure is destroyed and the plant performance is difficult to be guaranteed. Furthermore, replay attacks can hide the other attacks without stealthiness in actuators or physical layer, which is introduced in [29]. This condition like the criminal hacks into the monitor when he/she commits a crime. Those hidden attacks can wantonly break systems and not be detected because the measurements are covered by replay attacks. However, when the replay attacks are detected and eliminated by operators, the other attacks without stealthiness are naturally exposed to the defender. Hence, here we only consider detecting the replay attacks in sensors.

div.head: Stochastic Coding Scheme for Detecting Replay Attack
div.p: Different from the existing noisy control scheme in [26], in this section a stochastic coding scheme is firstly proposed to eliminate the system performance degradation effectively. For the detection purpose, the coding scheme generates covariance changes after the replay attack occurring. Then two detectors are designed based on the proposed stochastic coding scheme to detect the covariance changes caused by replay attacks.

div.head: Stochastic Coding Model
div.p: Since the recording data is extracted from the normal systems, it is difficult to detect the potential attack only by the general χ 2 detector. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a new method to expand the distinction between the past and current data, and further expose the attack. The following stochastic coding scheme is provided to achieve this task.
We transmit the sensor measurements coded by an additional signal to the controller as follows:
div.formula: Y c k =y k + y * k = Cx k + v k + y * k ,(6)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: where the addition signal is Gaussian white process, i.e., y
Then the receiver decodes the transmission packet as
div.formula: Y d k =Y c -y * k = y k = Cx k + v k .(7)
div.p: Obviously, from (7), the receiver obtains the real sensor measurements in normal systems, which demonstrates this method causes no performance degradation compared with [26].

Remark 3. In networked systems, the realization of coding schemes often requires the senders and receivers own the knowledge of coding signal simultaneously. Thus, here we establish the stochastic codes as deterministic pseudo-stochastic signals in practical application and use a group of seeds to previously save different pseudo-stochastic signals. Then, the sensor measurements can be coded according to the number of transmission packet rather than the transmission time. Furthermore, every stochastic value of the coding signal can be held for n sampling time, which is described as a special asynchronous coding problem. As n increase, the sender and receiver are easier to synchronize coding signals. And this asynchronous coding scheme for detecting the replay attacks will be studied in our future works.
As a result, the coding and decoding process under replay attack can be rewritten as
div.formula: Y c k =y k + y * k = Cx k + v k + y * k , Y d k =Y c k -y * k = Cx k + v k + (y * k -y * k ) =y k + ȳ * k ,(8)
div.p: where ȳ * k y ky * k , and ȳ * k ∼ N (0, 2Σ * ) only occur when the replay attacks exist. Remark 4. From (7), we know the decoded data in the controller is the same as the measurements of sensors, i.e., Y d k = y k . This implies stochastic code results in no influence in the normal systems. Conversely, a Gaussian stochastic signal ȳ * k is brought into the compromised system in (8) so that the covariance is increased when the replay attacks exist. However, in [26], it injects a stochastic signal into both normal and compromised systems to expose the replay attacks. But the controller performance reduces with the covariance of the stochastic signal increasing. Hence, comparing with [26], no performance degradation in normal systems is a superiority of the stochastic coding scheme.

Remark 5. This coding scheme is motivated by [25], but the strategies are different. Firstly, the coding scheme in [25] applies a multiplicative code to detect the false data injection attacks, while here we use additive code to detect the replay attacks. Moreover, the coding matrix in [25] is developed to break the necessary and sufficient condition of false data injection attacks. In this paper, we equip the coding scheme to generate covariance differences between normal and compromised systems.

div.head: Residual-based Detector
div.p: Owe to the injecting of the stochastic signal, the residual covariance occurs changes in the compromised system.
We first analyze the covariance of residual in normal systems and compromised systems. Denote e k = x kxk and z k = y k -C xk|k-1 , and then the estimation error system is
div.formula: e k+1 = (A -LCA)e k + (I -LC)w k -Lv k+1 .(9)
div.p: Combining (3), the steady-state of residual covariance is
div.formula: Σ z lim k→∞ E(z k z T k ) = CP C T + R.(10)
div.p: Next, the covariance of residual in the compromised system with stochastic coding scheme is studied. The prior estimate of the Kalman filter xk+1|k is rewritten as
div.formula: xk+1|k =Ax + Bu k = (A + BK)x k =(A + BK)(x k|k-1 + L(Y d k -C xk|k-1 )) =(A + BK)(I -LC)x k|k-1 + (A + BK)L(y k + ȳ * k ). A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Let A (A + BK)(I -LC) and B (A + BK)L, it follows xk+1|k -x k+1|k = A (x k|k-1 -x k|k-1 ) + B ȳ * k = A k+1 (x 0|-1 -x 0|-1 ) + k i=0 A k-i B ȳ * i .(11)
div.p: Combining with ( 8) and ( 11), the residual in the compromised system is
div.formula: z k = Y d k -C xk|k-1 = y k + ȳ * k -(C x k|k-1 + k-1 i=0 CA k-i-1 B ȳ * i ). (12
div.p: In the sequel, with ( 12), the steady-state of residual covariance is described as follows:
div.formula: Σ z lim k→∞ E(z k z T k ) = lim k→∞ E((y k -C x k|k-1 )(y k -C x k|k-1 ) T ) + 2Σ * + ∞ i=0 CA i BΣ * B T A iT C T =Σ z + 2Σ * + ∞ i=0 CA i BΣ * B T A iT C T . (13
) Define L = ∞ i=0 A i BΣ * B T A iT ,
div.p: which can be obtained by solving the following equations:
div.formula: L -A L A T =BΣ * B T .(14)
div.p: Furthermore, (13) can be rewritten as
div.formula: Σ z = Σ z + 2Σ * + CL C T . (15
div.p: Remark 6. The stochastic coding scheme transforms the detection problems of replay attacks to test the changes in residual covariance. Because the addition stochastic code is designed by the defender, the altered residual covariance is completely known. Hence, the main task of attack detection is finding a hypothesis testing to distinguish the two known Gaussian distributions with different covariances.
div.formula: Denote zk = [z T k-J+1 • • • z T k ] T , C = diag(C, • • • , C) ∈ R mJ×nJ , L = diag(L , • • • , L ) ∈ R nJ×nJ , Σ * = diag(Σ * , • • • , Σ * ) ∈ R mJ×mJ , ΣH0 = diag(Σ z , • • • , Σ z ) and ΣH1 = diag(Σ z , • • • , Σ z )
div.p: , where H 0 represents the systems is healthy and H 1 represents the systems is under attack.

Since the system is under white noise and stochastic code, the evaluated value of detector is a stochastic value in both normal and attacked systems, which implies it may have possibilities of false alarm and missed detection. Hence, we propose the design method of residual-based detector subject to FAR and ADR in the following theorem.

Theorem 1. Consider the system (5) equipped with the stochastic coding scheme ( 6)-( 8), and the attacker implements replay attacks into the sensors, then the following detector (16) can detect replay attacks.
div.formula: g k = zT k Σ-1 H1 zk H0 ≶ H1 τ.(16)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Furthermore, the threshold value τ and covariance matrix of coding signal Σ * can be obtained by the following optimization problem:
div.formula: min Σ * , ΣH 1 , L ,τ trΣ * s.t.        Σ * > 0, τ ≤ χ β λ min ( ΣH1 )τ /λ max ( ΣH0 ) ≥ χ α ΣH1 = ΣH0 + 2 Σ * + C L CT L -A L A T = B Σ * B T , (17
div.p: where α and β are given false alarm rate (FAR) and attack detection rate (ADR).
Proof: In order to detect replay attacks, we propose the following hypothesis testing:
div.formula: g k =z T k Σ-1 H1 zk H0 ≶ H1 τ.
div.p: However, the threshold value τ and covariance matrix ΣH1 relating to Σ * are to be designed to satisfy the requirements of FAR and ADR. Firstly, we intend to guarantee the FAR lower than a given value α, i.e.,
div.formula: F AR = prob(z T k Σ-1 H1 zk > τ |H 0 ) ≤ α,(18)
div.p: where
div.formula: zT k Σ-1 H1 zk ≤ λ max ( ΣH0 ) λ min ( ΣH1 ) zT k Σ-1 H0 zk .(19)
div.p: With ( 18) and ( 19), it obtains
div.formula: F AR = prob(z T k Σ-1 H1 zk > τ |H 0 ) ≤ prob( λ max ( ΣH0 ) λ min ( ΣH1 ) zT k Σ-1 H0 zk > τ |H 0 ) ≤ α.(20)
div.p: In the sequel, ( 18) is satisfied when we guarantee
div.formula: prob(z T k Σ-1 H0 zk > λ min ( ΣH1 ) λ max ( ΣH0 ) τ |H 0 ) ≤ α. (21
div.p: Since zT k Σ-1 H0 zk is standard χ 2 distribution under hypothesis H 0 , (18) can be written as
div.formula: λ min ( ΣH1 ) λ max ( ΣH0 ) τ ≥ χ α .(22)
div.p: Secondly, we further intend to guarantee the ADR larger than a given value β.
div.formula: ADR = prob(z T k Σ-1 H1 zk > τ |H 1 ) ≥ β. (23
div.p: Since zT k Σ-1 H1 zk is standard χ 2 distribution under hypothesis H 1 , we rewritten (23) as τ ≤ χ β . Finally, ( 14)-( 15), ( 22) and τ ≤ χ β constitute the limiting condition (17). The constraint condition in (17) is obviously convex set and the optimization problem ( 17) is convex optimization since λ min ( ΣH1 )τ /λ max ( ΣH0 ) is a concave function. The proof is completed. Remark 7. Since the additional code may increase the communication load, the data length of y * k should be designed as small as possible when the limiting conditions of FAR and ADR are satisfied. Thus, it needs the objective function trσ * be minimal. Remark 8. In the detector (16), we choose g k = zT k Σ -1 H1 zk rather than g k = zT k Σ -1 H0 zk in [12], and [17]. Such choice can effectively avoid the existence of the non-convex constraint conditions in (17). Thus, the similar choice is also applied in the following analysis for output-based detector.
div.formula: g k = zT k (Σ -1 H0 -Σ -1 H1 )z k in

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Output-based Detector
div.p: Further, we will use the information of sensor measurements to design an output-based detector, which may also be available to be applied to systems lacking state observers or filters.
Such systems can be modeled by the following augmented system.
div.formula: x k+1 xk+1 = A BK LCA A + BK -LCA x k xk + I LC w k + 0 L v k+1 , y k = C 0 x k xk + v k . (24
) Denote xk = x k xk , Ã = A BK LCA A + BK -LCA , E w = I LC , E v = 0 L , C = C 0 .
div.p: Then ( 24) can be rewritten as
div.formula: xk+1 = Ãx k + E w w k + E v v k+1 , y k = C xk + v k .(25)
div.p: Furthermore, the stochastic coding process in sensor data transceivers can be modeled as
div.formula: Y c k =y k + y * k = C xk + v k + y * k , Y d =Y c -y * k = C xk + v k .(26)
div.p: Based on the system model ( 25) and coding model ( 26), we first analyze the covariance of sensor outputs in normal systems. The state trajectory is described as
div.formula: xk = Ãk x0 + k-1 i=0 Ãk E w w(k -i -1) + k-1 i=0 Ãk E v v(k -i).
div.p: Then the state covariance is
div.formula: Σ x lim k→∞ E(x k xT k ) = ∞ i=0 Ãk E w QE T w ( Ãk ) T + ∞ i=0 Ãk E w RE T w ( Ãk ) T .(27) Define
Σ * v = ∞ i=0 Ãk E w QE T w ( Ãk ) T , Σ * w = ∞ i=0 Ãk E w RE T w ( Ãk ) T ,
div.p: which are the solutions of the following equations:
div.formula: Σ * w -ÃΣ * w ÃT = E w QE T w , Σ * v -ÃΣ * v ÃT = E v RE T v .(28)
div.p: Combining ( 27) and ( 28), we obtain
div.formula: Σ x = Σ * w + Σ * v ,(29)
div.p: and the steady-state covariance of sensor measurement y k is described as follows:
div.formula: Σ y = E(y k y T k ) = CΣ x CT + Σ v .(30)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: For the compromised system, its output equation can be modeled as the following form with the stochastic coding scheme.
div.formula: Y c k =y k + y * k = C x k + v k + y * k , Y d k =Y c k -y * k = C x k + v k + (y * k -y * k ) =y k + ȳ * k .(31)
div.p: Along the way, the covariance of sensor output is
div.formula: Σ y = E(Y d k (Y d k ) T ) = Σ y + 2Σ * .(32)
div.p: Remark 9. It is worthy to notice that the stochastic coding scheme transfers the detection for the replay attack to the form of detecting additive sensor faults, which is shown in ( 31)- (32). Since decoded sensor measurements are only influenced by the current value of ȳ * k , we can design the detector with the decoded sensor outputs. Especially, the general fault diagnosis problems implement the residual-based detector (16) since it is necessary to find a designed value independent of the fault historical information.
div.formula: Denote ȳk = [y T k-J+1 • • • y T k ] T , ΣH0 = diag(Σ y • • • Σ y ) and ΣH1 = diag(Σ y • • • Σ y ).
div.p: The design method of output-based detector is summarized in the following theorem.
Theorem 2. For the system (25) under replay attacks, we can design the following output-based detector (33) to expose the potential attack with stochastic code (26) and (31).
div.formula: g k = ȳT k Σ-1 H1 ȳk H0 ≶ H1 τ.(33)
div.p: Then we can obtain the threshold value τ and covariance matrix Σ * of the coding signal by the following optimization problem:
div.formula: min Σ * , ΣH 1 ,τ trΣ * s.t.    Σ * > 0, τ ≤ χ β λ min ( ΣH1 )τ /λ max ( ΣH0 ) ≥ χ α ΣH1 = ΣH0 + 2 Σ * .(34)
div.p: Proof: Similar as Theorem 1, we choose the following hypothesis testing:
div.formula: g k = ȳT k Σ-1 H1 ȳk H0 ≶ H1 τ.
div.p: Next, combing with the FAR and ADR, we propose the limiting conditions for the design of y * k . Firstly, in order to guarantee FAR lower than a given α, we denote
div.formula: F AR = prob(ȳ T k Σ-1 H1 ȳk > τ |H 0 ) ≤ prob( λ max ( ΣH0 ) λ min ( ΣH1 ) ȳT k Σ-1 H0 ȳk > τ |H 0 ) ≤ α,(35)
div.p: which follows
div.formula: prob(ȳ T k Σ-1 H0 ȳk > λ min ( ΣH1 ) λ max ( ΣH0 ) τ |H 1 ) ≤ α.
div.p: Then, based on the χ 2 distribution laws, ( 35) is equivalent to
div.formula: λ min ( ΣH1 ) λ max ( ΣH0 ) τ ≥ χ α .(36)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Secondly, combining with (33), in order to guarantee the ADR larger than a given β, i.e.,
div.formula: ADR =prob(ȳ T k Σ-1 H1 ȳk > τ |H 1 ) ≥ β, it should guarantee τ ≤ χ β Since ȳT k Σ-1
div.p: H1 ȳk is standard χ 2 distribution. Finally, combining (32), (36) and τ ≤ χ β , the optimization problem (34) is obtained. Similar as Theorem 1, the optimization problem ( 34) is convex optimization. The proof is completed.

Remark 10. From Theorem 1 and Theorem 2, it can be seen that ( 17) has more decision variables and equality equation constraint conditions than (34). Hence, the output-based detector design method (33) in Theorem 2 has less computation burden than the residual-based one (16) in Theorem 1. For example, for two-dimension systems, there are 9 decision variables and 10 constraint conditions in the optimization problem (17) and 6 decision variables and 7 constraint conditions in the optimization problem (34).

div.head: NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, a discrete-time RLC system is given to verify the effectiveness of residual-based and output-based detection scheme, simultaneously.

The circuit structure, current direction, information flow and attack location are shown in Fig. 2. Denote the resistance, inductance, capacitance, current and supply voltage as R, L, C, I and E, respectively. The two sensors, digital ammeter and voltmeter, are used to measure current and voltage on the capacitor, respectively. The measurements are transmitted to processing unit (computing control inputs and state estimations) by network communication, and process unit transmits the control signal to pulse width modulator (PWM) to control the supply voltage E over networks. Attacker replays the current and voltage measurements with past data over the networks. Finally, the detector collects the information in process unit to judge whether to alarm.
Borrowed from [31], then RLC system is described as
div.formula: x 1(k+1) x 2(k+1) = T RC -T R L + 1 -T RC T RC 1 -T RC x 1k x 2k + T R L 0 u k + w k , y 1k y 2k = 1 0 0 1 x 1k x 2k + v k ,
div.p: where x 1 = I is capacitor current, x 2 = e = (1/C) Idt is capacitor voltage and control input u = E is supply voltage. The process and measurement noises satisfy w k ∼ N (0, I) and v k ∼ N (0, I), respectively. Choose R = 10Ω, L = 10H, C = 0.1F and sampling interval T = 0.1s. To guarantee the closed-loop system stable, the filter and controller steady-state gains are designed as follows based on the principles in Section II. L = 0.619 0.0014 0.0014 0.5986 , K = -10.0838 -1.1313 .

Firstly, under the same 5% FAD and three different ADRs, the optimal results in our paper and [26] are given in Table I-II, respectively. It can be seen that the covariances Σ * in both [26] and our paper increase as the corresponding ADRs increase. Moreover, no performance degradation exists in our paper while the performance degradation J in [26] is bigger as the ADRs increase. Then, some simulation results of the stochastic coding scheme under replay attack will be given. Suppose the attacker records the sensor measurements for the first 5s, and replays them in the transmission channel between sensors and controller processing unit for the next 5s. Next, both the residual-based and output-based schemes are used to show the effectiveness. which is obtained by the optimization problem (17). The corresponding FAR and ADR limitations are chosen as α = 5% and β = 75%, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the evaluated value g k in normal systems, which is always lower than the threshold value τ . The detection condition in the compromised system is depicted in Fig. 4, and it is easy to see the detection rate against replay attack is significantly large after 5s, which implies the coding scheme can effectively expose the replay attack. To depict the performance of the designed coding signal and detector (16), the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve are given in Fig. 5. ROC curve is used to evaluate the diagnosis effect of the chosen statistic in hypothesis testing problems. In Fig. 6, the response curve of g k is shown, which is lower than τ . Fig. 7 exhibits the detection behavior of the stochastic coding scheme against the replay attack. It has been shown that the attack detection rate is very small before 5s and increases extremely large after 5s. The ROC curve of detector (33) is shown in Fig. 8 to reveal the performance of the output-based detector (33), which is similar with the performance of residual-based detector (16) in Case 1.

Moreover, it can be seen that the covariance Σ * of coding signal for the residual-based detector (16) in Case 2 is much larger than that for the output-based detector (33) 16), the output-based detector (33) has less communication loads and less design complexity in this example.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper studies the detection problems against replay attack in CPSs based on coding sensors transmitting information. The stochastic coding scheme injects a designed coding signal into the transmitted channel of sensors information, and it can further generate enough covariance differences between normal and compromised systems. In order to detect the covariance changes in the compromised system, the residual-based and output-based detectors are developed by the likelihoodrate test. In particular, this way achieves the detection objectives without sacrificing any system performances in normal systems. Given the false alarm rate and attack detection rate limitations, the design of stochastic coding signal is described as an optimization problem. Finally, a practical example is given to verify the effectiveness of the proposed code-based detection method. In the future, we will focus on the asynchronous coding scheme to further increase the data synchronization capability of senders and receivers for detecting replay attacks.

div.p: A N U S C R I P T
